conversations_v0.answer: In the 2010 census, the U.S. Census Bureau allowed respondents to self-identify their racial and ethnic backgrounds, including American Indian or Alaska Native ancestry. This marked a significant evolution from earlier census practices where the enumerator would determine the respondent's race. Starting in the 1960 census, individuals could choose their race, but it wasn't until the 2000 census that respondents could select more than one race. In addition, those identifying as American Indian or Alaska Native were given the opportunity to specify their enrolled or principal tribe. These changes were part of broader efforts to provide a more accurate representation of the U.S. population's diverse racial and ethnic identities.
